Includes estimate for remainder of program

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Families, Housing, Community Services and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 5 June 2008:

item.para: Is she aware of reports that the New South Wales Government is refusing to make available to the Commonwealth individual schools’ results in national literacy and numeracy tests. (2) Has the New South Wales Government been providing personal information to Centrelink about school students, including those reported as being ‘at risk’ and their attendance records. (3) Does she propose to quarantine the welfare payments of parents with children ‘at risk’ or who truant; if so, on what grounds will her proposal for welfare quarantining work.

talker.name: Macklin, Jenny, MP
talker.role: Minister for Families, Housing, Community Services and Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Ms Macklin

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: The Council of Australian Governments Agenda has already agreed a set of outcomes and reform directions. In schooling they focus on six key areas: (1) improving teacher quality and school leadership; (2) setting high standards and expectations; (3) boosting parental engagement; (4) greater accountability and better directed resources; (5) creating modern world-class learning environments, including in information and communication technologies; and (6) raising attainment levels in low socio-economic status communities.

(2 to 3) The 2008-09 Budget measure, Improving School Enrolment and Attendance through Welfare Reform, will introduce conditions on the receipt of income support payments whereby parents are obliged to ensure their children of compulsory school age are enrolled in school as well as take reasonable action to ensure children attend school regularly. The measure will initially be implemented in selected locations, including six sites in the NT, namely Hermannsburg, Katherine, Katherine town camps, Wallace Rockhole, Wadeye and Tiwi Islands, and two metropolitan locations outside of the NT. One of these will be in the suburb of Cannington in Perth, Western Australia. The other has yet to be decided.

For enrolment, parents will be required to inform Centrelink directly of the school at which their child is enrolled. For attendance, school authorities will be able to notify Centrelink where parents have not taken reasonable action to ensure their children attend school regularly. Centrelink will then notify parents of the consequences for non-compliance. Parents who persist in failing to meet their obligations without a reasonable excuse may have their income support payments suspended until they comply.

Before suspension is imposed, Centrelink will actively work with parents to assist them comply with their requirements and to determine whether parents have a reasonable excuse for their incapacity to comply. Once parents demonstrate they are taking reasonable steps to ensure their children are attending school, income support payments will be restored with back payment.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Families, Housing, Community Services and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 5 June 2008:

quote.para: In respect of Community Development Employment Projects (CDEP): has she received any departmental advice about the impact of reinstating CDEP in Northern Territory townships subject to the intervention, if so: (a) what does the advice indicate about the feasibility of quarantining the payments received by CDEP participants; (b) will reinstating CDEP help Aboriginal people find employment; and (c) will she release this advice to the public.

talker.name: Macklin, Jenny, MP
talker.role: Minister for Families, Housing, Community Services and Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Ms Macklin

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: Advice about reinstating CDEP in transitioned communities in the Northern Territory is clear that under existing legislation CDEP Scheme payments are not included in the categories of payments that are subject to the income management regime.

In areas where CDEP continues to operate in the Northern Territory, employment outcomes are being achieved and the availability of the program in the areas it was removed by the previous government is also expected to help Indigenous Australians move into non-CDEP employment.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Families, Housing, Community Services and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 5 June 2008:

item.para: Why will changes to card holder eligibility cost $19.4 million to administer; and what is the detailed breakdown of these expenses.
How many people will lose eligibility for the card as a result of the Budget’s changes to the eligibility criteria.

Has the Government changed its estimates for the costs of the Medicare Safety Net as result of the changes to card eligibility. (4) Is the Government aware that in some States the card provides eligibility for a range of concessions for seniors; has the Government discussed with the States the flow-on savings concerning the costs of providing these concessions; and is the Government planning to adjust State funding as a result.

talker.name: Macklin, Jenny, MP
talker.role: Minister for Families, Housing, Community Services and Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Ms Macklin

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

para.inline: Responsible Economic Management – Commonwealth Seniors Health Card – adjusted taxable income test.

item.para: Departmental expenses for the Department of Families, Housing, Community Services and Indigenous Affairs (FaHCSIA) to administer this measure are $18.37 million over four years, as shown in the 2008-09 Portfolio Budget Statements.
The majority of Centrelink costs are in 2008-09 and relate to changes to forms and publicity material, IT systems costs, and advising and reviewing customers.
Around 22,000 customers will lose eligibility in 2009-10.
Yes, these are reflected in the Health and Ageing portfolio.
The Commonwealth does not provide funding to the States and Territories for concessions they may offer Commonwealth Seniors Health Card holders. Any concessions provided are at their discretion.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Families, Housing, Community Services and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 5 June 2008:

quote.para: In respect of the Northern Territory Intervention: (a) what measures have been implemented to monitor alcohol sales, especially large purchases of alcohol by people who might be subject to the intervention’s measures; and (b) are alcohol sales of more than $100 supposed to be recorded, if so, (i) is this happening, (ii) are officials being notified of such sales, and (iii) what follow-up action is taken.

talker.name: Macklin, Jenny, MP
talker.role: Minister for Families, Housing, Community Services and Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Ms Macklin

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Under the Northern Territory National Emergency Response Act, provision was made to record takeaway alcohol sales in excess of 1350mls of liquor.

After its commencement a submission was received from representative bodies for licensees proposing a $100 measure as a clear and concise way for licensees and their staff to comply with their legal obligations under the Act. Prior to the introduction of the $100 threshold, licensees were required to calculate the alcohol content of each liquor item purchased to determine whether or not the 1350mls pure alcohol limit had been exceeded.
That case was accepted by the previous Government and the $100 limit was set for recording purposes.
The NT Government also collates data on wholesale liquor sales throughout the Northern Territory and this information is published on its web site.

item.label: (i)
item.para: Yes. All NT Licensing inspectors undertake compliance checks to ensure licensed premises are collecting this information in accordance with the requirements of the Act. Checks of the $100 register are a routine part of licensing checks at takeaway premises. From January to 9 May, 68 takeaway premises checks were undertaken (some covert) in Southern Region and 90 takeaway licence inspections in Northern Region. Except for covert checks, these included $100 register data.

The Australian Government also provided funding for 8 out of 12 additional Licensing Inspectors in the NT. Six of these positions became effective on 6 January, with a further two remote positions (Tennant Creek and Katherine) commencing in April due to difficulties associated with recruitment to remote localities.

The primary objective of the positions is to provide liquor regulatory and compliance services to targeted rural and remote areas, with a particular focus on the prescribed areas of the NTNER Act. In line with the funding agreement, the inspectors are expected to regularly visit NTER prescribed communities.

item.label: (ii)
item.para: The $100 register data is automatically included in the liquor permit system that operates in East Arnhem land, while a photo identification system operating in the Katherine region and Nhulunbuy is being programmed to produce an automated report on sales of $100 and over.

It is hoped that alcohol measures under the NTNER Act 2007 will add to inroads being made in supply reduction through the introduction of Liquor Supply plans. For instance, in Alice Springs there has been a 10.2% reduction in pure alcohol sales in the first 12 months after the plan’s introduction on 1 October 2006.

item.label: (iii)
item.para: Where recorded data indicates purchased alcohol is to be consumed in a prescribed area, such information is utilised to inform any investigations into offences.

My Department (FaHCSIA) is also currently working with Police and Licensing to examine the potential for the $100 register data to provide an ongoing basis of intelligence for surveillance in relation to alcohol purchases and potential breaches of the NTNER Act.
The $100 measure will be part of the NTER measures looked at under the Review.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 5 June 2008:

item.para: What is the outcome of the Medical Service Advisory Committee’s consideration of the work of the Peritoneal Centre at St George Hospital.

Can she indicate whether the establishment at St George Hospital of a national centre for excellence in the treatment of peritoneal cancer has been considered by the Australian Health Ministers’ Advisory Council;
Is such a centre likely to be funded by the Australian Health Care Agreement; if so, when.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: In November 2006, the assessment report of the Medical Services Advisory Committee (MSAC) titled ‘Peritonectomy: Assessment for Nationally Funded Centre Status – a report by the Medical Services Advisory Committee to the Australian Health Ministers’ Advisory Council’ was completed and provided to the Australian Health Ministers’ Advisory Council (AHMAC) for consideration.

This was in response to AHMAC’s request of June 2005 for advice from MSAC on the suitability of the technique of peritonectomy for support under the Nationally Funded Centre (NFC) program. The assessment in particular considered the suitability of the peritonectomy service at St George Hospital in Kogarah, NSW, as a potential provider of the service as an NFC.

MSAC considered that evidence for the effectiveness of peritonectomy in the treatment of pseudomyxoma and peritoneal mesothelioma was weak, and recommended that one centre undertake research and evaluation to determine the effectiveness of this service in the long term.
The report is available on the MSAC website at www.msac.gov.au.

Based on advice received from the NFC Reference Group, AHMAC confirmed at its 13 June 2007 meeting that NFC status would not be conferred for this procedure. This decision was conveyed to the St George Hospital in October 2007.

Since 1998, the Commonwealth has broadbanded its NFC contributions through the Australian Health Care Agreements (AHCAs). The Commonwealth and the States and Territories are currently working together to develop new national health care agreements. These are expected to be signed by December 2008 and commence in July 2009. Clarification of the respective roles and responsibilities of the Commonwealth and the States and Territories is part of this process. Therefore it is not possible to comment on whether a nationally funded centre for peritoneal cancer is likely to be funded at this time.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment Participation, in writing, on 5 June 2008:

item.para: Will the Government continue running the trial program under which unemployed people attend an interview with a Centrelink officer every two weeks to review their job seeking activity.
What is the total number of unemployed people who have taken part in this program; and how many of them have found jobs while on this program.
How does this compare with the success rate of job seekers not on the program.
Has there been a review of this program; if so, has the program been effective for encouraging people on employment benefits to find work.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The Welfare to Work Contact Model, in its trial form, ceased operating from 30 June 2008. Participants in the pilot who wish to continue with increased reporting will be given the option to continue.

The highest level of participation in the Contact Model was in March 2007 where approximately 95,000 job seekers had been converted from standard reporting to the Contact Model arrangements. Due to a range of factors, including differing target job seeker groups participating in the pilot, employment outcomes varied.

An evaluation of the Contact Model was completed in late 2007. The evaluation compared the difference between outcomes achieved at Contact Model sites with outcomes from similar Centrelink sites that did not operate the Contact Model.
The evaluation identified some outcomes from the engagement of job seekers via the Contact Model; the results of the trial produced mixed outcomes.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 5 June 2008:

quote.para: For each year since 1996-97: (a) how many breaches of Regulation 13E under the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations 1958 have been identified; and (b) how many prosecutions were undertaken in relation to persons and/or companies, and (i) what was the outcome of each prosecution, and (ii) for each identified breach and/or prosecution, what export controlled goods, technology or information were involved.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: 2005-06: 2 breaches – 1 x controlled materials and 1 x information security.
2006-07: 22 breaches – 8 x chemicals, 1 x chemical/military, 11 x military, 1 x telecommunications and 1 x material process.
2007-08: 17 breaches – 8 x chemicals, 4 x military, 1 x telecommunications, 1 x telecommunications/electronic and 1 x avionics.

These breaches relate to available records from mid-2006. Details of breaches prior to this period are contained in archived paper files and are not readily available. Were Defence to expend the time or the resources required to provide similar data from 1996-2006, this would delay approval of export permission and exports from Australia.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Prosecutions for breaches of Regulation 13E of the Customs Act 1901 are undertaken by the Australian Customs Service. Customs has prosecuted two cases for defence-related goods.

item.label: (i)
item.para: The first offence took place on 13 February 2003 and the hearing was held on 7 February 2006. The defendants were found guilty and fined $13,000 and the goods forfeited to the Crown.
The second offence took place on or about 1 March 2003 and the hearing was held on 30 May 2006. The defendant was found guilty of five charges but successfully appealed four of the five charges.

item.label: (ii)
item.para: The goods involved in both prosecutions mentioned above were military items. For information on the goods involved in other breaches, see (a) above.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 5 June 2008:

quote.para: For each year since 1996-97, how many staff were employed in the Defence Export Control Office in the Department of Defence and what was the Office’s annual budget.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, in writing, on 4 June 2008:

item.para: According to the Cabinet Handbook, are hard copies of any Cabinet documents held by vacating Ministers (and their staff) required to be returned to the Cabinet Secretariat or destroyed under the provisions of the Protective Security Manual.
In respect of the disposal of Cabinet submissions, memoranda, corrigenda and minutes: is a record of the status of each one (including the copy number) maintained for records management purposes.

Is he able to confirm that, after the November 2007 general election, every Cabinet document held by all outgoing Ministerial staff was returned or destroyed in accordance with the requirements of the Cabinet Handbook and the Protective Security Manual.
Is he able to confirm whether any former Ministers have not returned or destroyed all Cabinet documents held by them or their former Office.

talk.start.para: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Cabinet documents are required to be destroyed by vacating ministers’ staff in accordance with the provisions of the Protective Security Manual.

I am advised that immediately following the 2007 election, the Cabinet Secretariat wrote to all outgoing ministers and parliamentary secretaries advising that all Cabinet documents were to be destroyed and providing guidance on the appropriate procedures for destroying any hardcopy Cabinet documents. Assurances were also requested to be provided to the Secretariat once destruction had occurred. The Cabinet Secretariat subsequently followed-up with phone calls to all ministers’ and parliamentary secretaries’ offices. The Cabinet Secretariat received written and/or verbal confirmation from 90 per cent of all outgoing ministers and parliamentary secretaries that they no longer held any documents.

I am advised that, to the best of its knowledge, the Cabinet Secretariat is confident that ministers and parliamentary secretaries followed correct procedures and destroyed all Cabinet documents allocated to them.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 16 June 2008:

quote.para: In respect of the mandatory addition of folate to wheat flour for making bread, taking effect from 13 September 2009: (a) what additional requirements will be placed on the flour milling industry as a result of the initiative; (b) is she aware that sections of the flour milling industry, particularly smaller producers, claim that the initiative will render them uncompetitive in the market place and lead to closures; and (c) has the Government taken any action to mitigate the impact of the initiative on the flour milling industry; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: Consultation with industry by Food Standards Australia New Zealand (FSANZ) has identified that most flour mills in Australia will require an upgrade to equipment in order to implement mandatory fortification of flour for making bread with folic acid.

item.label: (c)
item.para: FSANZ is currently consulting with flour millers and fortification experts internationally to further examine the ranges of folic acid in flour being achieved and the equipment and processes used, in order to minimize the impact of this initiative on the flour milling industry.

The Australia New Zealand Food Regulation Ministerial Council has also taken steps to address the issues about compliance and enforcement of the folic acid Standard. The Implementation Sub-Committee has established a working group to develop a compliance and enforcement model for folic acid fortification that can be adopted by industry and jurisdictional enforcement agencies.

The compliance and enforcement model will consider the compliance of industry with the specified range of folic acid and assist with the implementation of the Standard. FSANZ is currently developing an Industry User Guide to assist industry, expected to be released later in 2008.

FSANZ consulted and engaged with industry at all stages in the development of the mandatory folic acid fortification Standard. FSANZ will continue to work with industry to help address the implementation issues around this new Standard.

subdebateinfo.title: Bringing Nurses Back into the Workforce Program

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 16 June 2008:

quote.para: Does the Government intend to increase the level of health services provided outside of the hospital system; if so, will the Government extend the Bringing Nurses Back into the Workforce program to the community nursing sector; and if this program will not be extended, what are the reasons.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: The primary focus of the Bringing Nurses Back into the Workforce program is to address the nursing shortage in our hospitals and there are no plans to expand this into the community setting. Government funding currently provides support for nurses in community settings, including re-entry and education and training programs and scholarships.
In addition to the increased services to the hospital system, the Government is investing in strengthening community health services through:

item.para: a range of commitments such as GP super clinics and support for Nurses in General Practice; and

the development of a National Primary Health Care Strategy to support the community health workforce in the medium term by promoting evidence-based management of chronic disease. This strategy will focus on:
supporting patients with chronic disease to manage their condition;
supporting the role GPs play in the health care team;
addressing the growing need for access to other health professionals including practice nurses and allied health professionals like physiotherapists and dieticians; and
encouraging a greater focus on multidisciplinary team-based care.

quote.para: These initiatives will provide support for the community nursing sector.
The Australian Government recognises and values the vital work that nurses undertake in every sector of our health care system.

I am pleased to advise that Ms Rosemary Bryant was appointed to the position of Commonwealth Chief Nurse and Midwifery Officer (CCNMO) on 22 June 2008. The role of CCNMO was established to build and strengthen nursing leadership nationally and provide a national perspective and strategic, collaborative approach on nursing workforce planning, strategy and education.

Nursing education and training is an area of significant investment by the Australian Government, a recognition that reflects the important contribution nurses make to the Australian health care system. The Australian Government has committed funding for an additional 1,170 ongoing university nursing places per year.

The Australian Government plans to develop a national maternity services plan to ensure national coordination of maternity services. The first step in developing this plan is to undertake the Maternity Services Review, which will consider a range of issues relevant to the full range of maternity services, including the important role of midwives.

The work of the National Health and Hospital Reform Commission (NHHRC) and the Council of Australian Governments (COAG) will inform development of further strategies to build an effective and sustainable workforce for the future.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Families, Housing, Community Services and Indigenous Affairs, in writing, on 18 June 2008:

item.para: From what date does she envisage that compulsory welfare quarantining will take place in Cape York, the Kimberley and elsewhere in Australia in respect of families whose children do not regularly attend school or whose children are thought by child protection authorities to be ‘at risk’.
From what date does she envisage that welfare dependent families in these same areas will be able to voluntarily seek family income management through Centrelink

talker.name: Macklin, Jenny, MP
talker.role: Minister for Families, Housing, Community Services and Indigenous Affairs
talker.name: Ms Macklin

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: In cases of child neglect, the Western Australian Department for Child Protection will be able to request compulsory income management of parents in receipt of welfare payments in the Kimberley and Cannington areas of Western Australia from September 2008.

The Improving School Enrolment and Attendance through Welfare Reform measure will commence from the start of the 2009 school year. Income management or ‘quarantining of payments’ will not be used as part of this measure. The Government proposes to legislate to provide for income support payments to be temporarily suspended until parents make adequate effort to enrol their children in school and ensure they attend.
Operation of the Cape York measure will commence early in the 2008/09 financial year, subject to the finalisation of details with the Queensland government.
Under the Cape York measure individuals may approach the Families Responsibilities Commission to be voluntarily income managed. These referrals may be made from the commencement of this measure.
Voluntary Income Management is expected to be activated in conjunction with the Child Protection measure in the Kimberley and Cannington areas of Western Australia only.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment, Heritage and the Arts, in writing, on 24 June 2008:

quote.para: Is Aurora Australis being hired by the Japanese Government to support its activities in the Antarctic Territory; if so, does this compromise the integrity of Australia’s attempts to protect whales.

talker.name: Garrett, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for the Environment, Heritage and the Arts
talker.name: Mr Garrett

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: Aurora Australis will conduct the annual logistic resupply of the Japanese Antarctic station Syowa and in transit, will conduct some marine science on behalf of the Japanese Institute of Polar Research.

The conduct of marine science on this voyage will not compromise the integrity of Australia’s efforts to protect whales. No whaling related research will be conducted during the voyage. The Japanese Institute of Polar Research is unrelated to the Institute for Cetacean Research (that conducts Japan’s whaling operations), and the research that is being conducted accords with Australia’s own Antarctic research efforts.

subdebateinfo.title: Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government: Regional Offices

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, in writing, on 24 June 2008:

quote.para: Has the Government closed regional offices of his department; if so, (a) where, and (b) how many staff have had their positions terminated.

talker.name: Albanese, Anthony, MP
talker.role: Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government
talker.name: Mr Albanese

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: No.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, in writing, on 25 June 2008:

asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, in writing, on 25 June 2008:

item.para: Can she indicate the Government’s reaction to the reported decision of the Government of the Republic of Indonesia to cease case-by-case reporting to the World Health Organization of infections and deaths arising from the H5N1 strain of avian influenza.
Is she satisfied that Indonesia is currently complying with International Health Regulations concerning reporting human cases of, and deaths from, avian influenza.
Has the Government made representations concerning this issue to the relevant Indonesian authorities; is so, what are the details.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: The Australian Government has sought clarification from authorities in Indonesia concerning recent reports of changes to Indonesia's policy on public announcement of human cases of H5N1 avian influenza. The Government understands that Indonesia has continued to report cases to the World Health Organization (WHO) since the reported policy change.

The WHO is the appropriate body to provide comment on compliance with the International Health Regulations. WHO Assistant Director-General David Heymann has stated that Indonesia has told WHO that it will continue to report avian influenza cases in accordance with the International Health Regulations.
The Australian Government has sought clarification on this issue from Indonesian authorities.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 25 June 2008:

item.para: What protocol, agreement or arrangement between the Australian and United States governments has governed the operations of United States Secret Service personnel accompanying the United States President, Vice President and/or Cabinet members during visits to Australia.
Are United States Secret Service personnel permitted to carry firearms when accompanying the United States President, Vice President and/or Cabinet members during visits to Australia.
What arrangements are in place concerning civil and criminal liability in relation to actions by United States Secret Service agents in Australia.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: There is no protocol, agreement or arrangement between the Australian and United States governments that governs the operations of the United States Secret Service personnel who accompany the United States President, Vice President and/or Cabinet members during visits to Australia.

The Australian Government has a longstanding policy of not permitting the importation and carriage of weapons by foreign security personnel. Foreign governments may formally seek exemptions to this policy, and the Australian Government considers any such request on a case by case basis. Consistently with this policy, specific security arrangements are not discussed publicly.

There are no specific arrangements in place concerning civil and criminal liability in relation to actions by United States Secret Service agents in Australia. These individuals remain at all times subject to relevant Australian law.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 25 June 2008:

quote.para: Which Australian ports are currently approved to receive visits by nuclear powered warships; and when was the suitability of each port to receive such visits last re-validated.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: The re-validation of Nuclear Powered Warship ports is conducted at two yearly intervals and, in accordance with extant procedures, if the port has not had a visit in the preceding 12 months a validation will be conducted prior to any planned visit.

Hobart (Tas) was last visited by a Nuclear Powered Warship in May 2002, and was last revalidated in December 2005. The Visiting Ships Panel (Nuclear) is currently considering when this port should again be validated.

Jervis Bay (NSW/ACT) is a secondary port and last received a visit in 1983. Jervis Bay was last revalidated in December 2005. The revalidation process is underway, but is delayed while local authorities redraft the Port Safety Plan.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 25 June 2008:

asked the Minister for Defence, in writing, on 25 June 2008:

quote.para: In respect of the response to question No. 4990 (Hansard, 26 February 2007, page 198) concerning the Defence property located at Allara Street in Civic ACT: can he indicate what the “original purpose of the site from the 1960s to early 1970s” was.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

quote.para: No. Defence has been unable to substantiate this purpose due to the unavailability of records for that period. The site on Allara Street was empty prior to the commencement of construction of the depot in the late 1960s. The depot was purpose built for the Army Reserve, specifically the 3rd Battalion, The Royal New South Wales Regiment and the Australian National University Company of the Sydney University Regiment. There were no other users of this site between 1968 and 1972.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 25 June 2008:

item.para: Can he indicate whether the Government made any inquiries of: (a) the Government of Pakistan, (b) the Government of Egypt; and/or (c) the United States (US) Government to determine the precise circumstances of Mr Habib’s transfer from (i) Pakistan to Egypt, and (ii) Egypt to Afghanistan.
Can he indicate whether his department or any other agency within his portfolio first learnt that Mr Habib was detained in Pakistan.

Can he indicate whether Australian law enforcement or other officers had any discussions with Pakistani officials concerning Mr Habib while he was detained in Pakistan; if so, on what dates did these discussions occur.
Can he indicate whether Australian law enforcement or other officers had any contact with Mr Habib while he was detained in Pakistan; if so, on what dates did this contact occur.
Can he indicate whether Australian law enforcement or other agencies provided Pakistani officials with any information concerning Mr Habib while he was detained in Pakistan.
Can he indicate when his department or any other agency within his portfolio first became aware of Mr Habib’s detainment in Egypt.
Can he indicate whether Australian law enforcement or other officers had any contact with Mr Habib while he was detained in Egypt; if so, on what dates did this contact occur.
Can he indicate whether Australian law enforcement or other officers had any discussions with Egyptian officials concerning Mr Habib while he was detained in Egypt.
Can he indicate whether Australian law enforcement or other officers provided Egyptian officials with any information concerning Mr Habib while he was detained in Egypt.
Can he provide details on the explanation the US Government gave concerning Mr Habib’s transfer from Egypt into US military custody in April 2002.

Can he indicate what specific inquiries his department or other agencies within his portfolio undertook in respect of allegations that Mr Habib was subjected to torture or inhumane treatment while he was detained in: (a) Pakistan; (b) Egypt; and (c) US military custody.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.label: (1) (a)
item.para: This question is best directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. However, I am advised that at the time the Government became aware of Mr Habib’s possible detention in Pakistan in early October 2001, representations were made on a number of occasions to Pakistani officials in Islamabad, seeking confirmation of Mr Habib’s detention and seeking consular access. Consular access was denied by Pakistan. Notwithstanding that the Australian Government formed a view in mid to late November that Mr Habib was most likely in Egypt, the Australian Embassy continued to make representations to Pakistani officials seeking information on Mr Habib until mid January 2002. (b) This question is best directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. However, I am advised that the Department became aware in November 2001 that Mr Habib was no longer in Pakistan and that he may have been transferred to Egypt. Between November 2001 and April 2002, the Australian Embassy in Cairo made representations to the Egyptian Government on a number of occasions, including at the highest levels, seeking confirmation of Mr Habib’s detention in Egypt and seeking consular access to him. However, the Government of Egypt has never officially confirmed that it held Mr Habib in its custody.. (c) I am advised that Australian authorities were notified on 16 April 2002 that Mr Habib was in United States custody.
Yes. As stated in response to question number 196 taken on notice by ASIO during an Estimates hearing of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee on 15 February 2005:
“ASIO received notification on 6 October 2001 that an Australian man had been taken into custody by Pakistani authorities. On 8 October 2001 it was confirmed that the man was Mamdouh Habib.”

Yes. I am advised that upon notification of Mr Habib’s apprehension in Pakistan, the AFP commenced an investigation with a view to determining whether Mr Habib had breached any Australian laws. As with all investigations, the AFP communicated with relevant partner agencies as required. I am advised that ASIO had discussions with Pakistani officials concerning Mr Habib on a number of occasions from around late October 2001. It is not appropriate to comment further.
Yes. I am advised that Mr Habib was interviewed by ASIO on 24 October 2001 and by ASIO and AFP officers on 26 and 29 October 2001.
I am advised that the Department has no record of how it became aware that Mr Habib may have been in Egypt.
The former Director-General of ASIO, in testimony before the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee on 15 February 2005, said:

“We formed a view in mid to late November that he (Mr Habib) was most likely in Egypt, and that was the basis of the Foreign Affairs’ representation to the Egyptian authorities for consular access to him. We established to our satisfaction that he was definitely there in February 2002.”
The AFP has previously stated, in response to question 232 taken on notice during an Estimates hearing of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee on 15 February 2005 that:
“The AFP became aware on 19 November that Mr Habib was no longer in Pakistan and was most likely to be in Egypt.”
However, the Government of Egypt has never officially confirmed that it held Mr Habib in its custody, despite numerous representations by the Australian Government, including at the highest levels.

I am advised that the Australian Government made representations to the Egyptian Government on a number of occasions to seek confirmation of Mr Habib’s detention and seek access to him. Mr Habib’s detention was never confirmed and therefore no Australian government officer had contact with Mr Habib in Egypt.

The Australian Government made representations to the Egyptian Government on a number of occasions to seek confirmation of Mr Habib’s detention and seek access to him. Mr Habib’s detention was never confirmed.
I am advised that no explanation was given.

I am advised that the Department was not involved in making specific inquiries in respect of allegations that Mr Habib was subjected to torture or inhumane treatment while he was detained abroad. I note that the welfare of Australian citizens abroad is a matter for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade as part of its consular assistance role. I therefore refer you to the response provided by the Minister for Foreign Affairs to question 169 addressed to him in writing by you on 25 June 2008. The Minister’s response is as follows:

“I am advised that the Australian officials who visited Mr Habib on 24, 26 and 29 October 2001 reported that they saw no evidence to indicate he was maltreated. In light of the allegations made by Mr Habib on television on 13 February 2005, the Department requested the Australian Embassy in Islamabad to make representations to the Pakistani Government to investigate Mr Habib’s claims. In response, Pakistani authorities advised that an investigation into allegations of mistreatment of Mr Habib had been completed and no evidence of torture or humiliation had been found.

I am advised that in light of the allegations made by Mr Habib on television on 13 February 2005, the Department requested the Australian Embassy in Cairo to make representations to the Egyptian Government to investigate Mr Habib’s claims. In response, Egyptian authorities reiterated earlier advice that no evidence had been found of Mr Habib’s alleged detention and torture in Egypt.

I am advised that at the request of the Australian Government, there have been two investigations into Mr Habib’s treatment while in US custody. On 23 August 2004, the United States Department of Defense advised Australia’s Ambassador to the United States that an examination of medical records and other documents concerning the detention of Mr Habib had revealed no information to support the allegations of abuse. Similarly, on 15 July 2005, US authorities advised Australia’s ambassador to the United States that the US Naval Criminal Investigative Service (NCIS) had undertaken a separate and comprehensive investigation into the allegations that Mr Habib had been abused. The NCIS advised that it undertook an exhaustive review of all records found pertaining to the detention of Mr Habib, and that Navy investigators interviewed Department of Defense, military and medical personnel, other United States Government personnel, federal law enforcement personnel and other detainees. The NCIS investigation found no information to substantiate or corroborate the allegations of abuse. These findings are consistent with reports by Australian officials who regularly visited Mr Habib at Guantanamo Bay. Australian officials visited Mr Habib on 11 occasions in Guantanamo Bay. On each occasion, his welfare was assessed. No evidence of maltreatment or abuse was found.

The Department also inquired about the US Department of Justice report released in May 2008 which in part referred to the conditions of Mr Habib’s interrogation at Guantanamo Bay in 2004. The Department is seeking from US authorities further details of these incidents and clarification of this report.”

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in writing, on 25 June 2008:

item.para: Is he able to indicate by what means his department first became aware of the possible detention of Mr Habib by Pakistani authorities in early October 2001.
Is he able to indicate by what means his department sought to confirm Mr Habib’s detention in Pakistan, and when confirmation was obtained.
Is he able to indicate by what means his department became aware in November 2001 that Mr Habib was no longer in Pakistan and that he may have been transferred to Egypt.

Is he able to indicate when and by what means (including advice from other Australian agencies) his department subsequently received confirmation that Mr Habib was detained in Egypt (either prior to, or after, Mr Habib’s transfer to Afghanistan).

Is he able to indicate what specific inquiries his department undertook in respect of allegations that Mr Habib was subjected to torture or inhumane treatment while he was detained in: (a) Pakistan; (b) Egypt, and (c) United States military custody.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: and (2) I am advised that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade became aware, through law enforcement and security channels, of the possible detention of Mr Habib by Pakistani authorities in early October 2001. The Australian Embassy in Islamabad made representations on a number of occasions to Pakistani officials seeking confirmation of Mr Habib’s detention and consular access to him. Consular access was denied by Pakistan. Australian security officials, however, visited Mr Habib on 24, 26 and 29 October 2001 in Pakistan. Australian law enforcement officials were also present at the meetings of 26 and 29 October 2001.

and (4) I am advised that the Department has no record of how it became aware that Mr Habib may have been in Egypt. The former Director-General of ASIO, in testimony before the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee on 15 February 2005, said that “We formed a view in mid to late November that he (Mr Habib) was most likely in Egypt, and that was the basis of the Foreign Affairs representation to the Egyptian authorities for consular access to him. We established to our satisfaction that he was definitely there in February 2002.” The Government of Egypt, however, has never officially confirmed that it held Mr Habib in its custody, despite numerous representations by the Australian Government, including at the highest levels.

item.label: (a)
item.para: I am advised that the Australian officials who visited Mr Habib on 24, 26 and 29 October 2001 reported that they saw no evidence to indicate he was maltreated. In light of the allegations made by Mr Habib on television on 13 February 2005, the Department requested the Australian Embassy in Islamabad to make representations to the Pakistani Government to investigate Mr Habib’s claims. In response, Pakistani authorities advised that an investigation into allegations of mistreatment of Mr Habib had been completed and no evidence of torture or humiliation had been found.

item.label: (b)
item.para: I am advised that in light of the allegations made by Mr Habib on television on 13 February 2005, the Department requested the Australian Embassy in Cairo to make representations to the Egyptian Government to investigate Mr Habib’s claims. In response, Egyptian authorities reiterated earlier advice that no evidence had been found of Mr Habib’s alleged detention and torture in Egypt.

item.label: (c)
item.para: I am advised that at the request of the Australian Government, there have been two investigations into Mr Habib’s treatment while in US custody. On 23 August 2004, the United States Department of Defense advised Australia’s Ambassador to the United States that an examination of medical records and other documents concerning the detention of Mr Habib had revealed no evidence of mistreatment or abuse while in United States Department of Defence custody. Similarly, on 15 July 2005 US authorities advised Australia’s Ambassador to the United States that the US Naval Criminal Investigative Service (NCIS) had undertaken a separate and comprehensive investigation into the allegations that Mr Habib had been abused. The NCIS advised that it undertook an exhaustive review of all records found pertaining to the detention of Mr Habib, and that Navy investigators interviewed Department of Defense, military and medical personnel, other United States Government personnel, federal law enforcement personnel and other detainees. The NCIS investigation found no information to substantiate or corroborate the allegations of abuse. These findings are consistent with reports by Australian officials who regularly visited Mr Habib at Guantanamo Bay. Australian officials visited Mr Habib on 11 occasions in Guantanamo Bay. On each occasion, his welfare was assessed. No evidence of maltreatment or abuse was found.

The Department also inquired about the US Department of Justice report released in May 2008 which in part referred to the conditions of Mr Habib’s interrogation at Guantanamo Bay in 2004. The Department is seeking from US authorities’ further details of these incidents and clarification of this report.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, in writing, on 25 June 2008:

item.para: Can he confirm that it is the position of the Government that the following interrogation techniques constitute torture: (a) extended sleep deprivation; (b) exposure to extreme cold for extended periods; and/or (c) immobilising a person and pouring water on his or her face to simulate drowning.

Can he state whether the Government has knowledge of the use of these techniques by United States (US) Government personnel engaged in the interrogation of persons suspected of involvement in terrorist activities.

Can he indicate when the Government departments or agencies first become aware of the US Government’s practice of “extraordinary renditions” to transfer persons suspected of terrorist activities or associations to countries where information may be obtained from them by means of interrogation.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Any act by a public official (or other person acting in an official capacity) specifically intended to inflict severe physical or mental pain or suffering for particular purposes is torture under international law. Australian agencies do not practise extended sleep deprivation, exposure to extreme cold for extended periods or immobilising a person and pouring water on his or her face to simulate drowning, and the Australian Government does not condone these practices.

The use of such techniques has been the subject of media and other speculation for some time. The Government is aware of public statements by United States Government officials relating to the use of various interrogation techniques.

I am advised that it is not possible to specify exactly when the Attorney-General’s Department or portfolio agencies first became aware of the United States Government’s practice of ‘extraordinary rendition’ of persons suspected of terrorist activities. I am advised that the Department is aware of a United States State Department report ‘Patterns of Global Terrorism’ 1998 which refers to the extradition and rendition of terrorists to the United States,

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment, Heritage and the Arts, in writing, on 26 June 2008:

item.para: Since becoming the Minister for Environment, Heritage and the Arts, has he visited the site for the proposed Traveston Crossing Dam in the company of Mr Graeme Newton of Queensland Water Infrastructure.
Can he indicate whether the Hon Anthony Albanese MP, when Shadow Minister for Water, visited the site for the proposed Traveston Crossing Dam during 2007 in the company of Mr Newton.
Will he provide equal time to listen to the views of opponents of the Traveston Crossing Dam as he has spent with Mr Newton; if not, why not.
Has he accepted hospitality from proponents of the proposed Traveston Crossing Dam.
Is he aware of a perception that such acceptance of hospitality could potentially compromise his capacity to independently evaluate the outcome of the environmental impact assessment of the project.

talker.name: Garrett, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for the Environment, Heritage and the Arts
talker.name: Mr Garrett

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: Yes, I visited the site on 3 March 2008.
This question should be directed to the Hon Anthony Albanese MP, Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government.

During my visit to Gympie, Kandanga, the site of the proposed Traveston Crossing Dam and environs on 3 March 2008 I met with representatives from a number of groups who oppose the proposed dam. Consistent with the requirements of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999, I will ensure that I have all the information I need before me to make a fully informed decision, including both the public comments in response to the Draft Environmental Impact Statement (‘EIS’) and the response of the proponent to those comments.

During the visit to the project site a light afternoon tea was provided by Queensland Water Infrastructure, proponents of Traveston Crossing Dam. The representatives of the community groups also provided refreshments for my staff and I during our meeting later that afternoon.

I do not agree that my acceptance of light refreshments, whether provided by the proponent or the community groups, will create the perception suggested in the question. My decision on the proposed Traveston Crossing Dam will be evidence-based and according to law.

talker.name: Garrett, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for the Environment, Heritage and the Arts
talker.name: Mr Garrett

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: I am not aware of any such assurances having been given.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment, Heritage and the Arts, in writing, on 26 June 2008:

item.para: Is he aware of statements by the Queensland Treasurer in State Parliament on 15 May 2008 that the Queensland Government has already spent $500 million on the Traveston Crossing Dam project.
Has he received the environmental impact statement for this project.
Does the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 preclude the commencement of a project before approvals have been completed.

If he has not received the environmental impact statement for this project and if the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 precludes the commencement of a project before approvals have been completed, will he halt the construction of the Traveston Crossing Dam until it is appropriate to proceed; if not, why not.

talker.name: Garrett, Peter, MP
talker.role: Minister for the Environment, Heritage and the Arts
talker.name: Mr Garrett

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: I am aware that the Queensland Treasurer, Mr Andrew Fraser, on 13 May 2008, referred to a $500 million investment for the proposed Traveston Crossing Dam. This was in relation to a question without notice from a Queensland Opposition Member of Parliament regarding the Queensland Opposition’s plan to climate proof south-east Queensland’s water supplies, including scrapping the Traveston Crossing Dam proposal.

The Draft Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) was received by my Department on 18 October 2007, and was subsequently open for public comments until 14 January 2008. The Supplementary Report to the EIS, which will take the public comments into account, is still being finalised by the proponent. My decision-making role under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 commences upon receipt of the Queensland Coordinator-General’s Assessment Report which follows the finalisation of the Supplementary Report.
The EPBC Act precludes the commencement of an action before the assessment process is complete and a decision made on the proposal.

Construction of the Traveston Crossing Dam has not commenced. I am aware that various investigative geotechnical and other works have been undertaken by the proponent to inform the environmental impact assessment process and other design related aspects of the proposal. My Department was notified of these activities, however such works are not considered part of the action referred for the purposes of assessment and approval under the EPBC Act, which is the construction and operation of the Traveston Crossing Dam. Accordingly, the question of halting the project until it is appropriate to proceed does not arise.
